title: queen shines church princess anne cold
story: The Queen, , was shining as she entered the church for morning service donning a bright orange jacket just days after cancelling an appearance because she had a cold.She was joined by Princess Anne, , who walked a small group of esteemed guests to the service while the Queen was riding in a chauffeur-driven maroon Bentley.Her Majesty wrapped up warm in a bright orange jacket and a furry black hat.Her dazzling appearance comes just days after the -year-old pulled out of an annual visit to the branch of the Womens Institute in Norfolk because she was not feeling up to it.Her Majesty cancelled her trip to the meeting in Norfolk at West Newton village hall with just  minutes notice.Despite feeling under the weather days prior, the Queen was smiling this morning as she sat in the back of the driven car alongside opera singer Dame Kiri Jeanette Claire Te Kanawa.Along with her fur hat, Her Majesty donned matching gloves on the crisp January morning.Princess Anne accompanied former British Formula One racing driver Sir Jackie Stewart on foot - chatting as they walked to the service.The Princess Royal was seen wearing a smart navy coat and light blue scarf with a feathered hat for the service.The Queens cheery appearance this morning comes after a tumultuous few weeks for the Royal Family which saw Prince Harry and Meghan Markle quit as royals.Harry sat down with his grandmother to thrash out details of the so-called Megxit - with it decided the couple would pay back the £.m of taxpayer money spent on refurbishing Frogmore Cottage.Announcing the decision, the Queen said the pair, and their eight-month-old son Archie, would always be much loved members of her family.She said: I recognise the challenges they have experienced as a result of intense scrutiny over the last two years and support their wish for a more independent le.I want to thank them for all their dedicated work across this country, the Commonwealth and beyond, and am particularly proud of how Meghan has so quickly become one of the family.It is my whole family’s hope that today’s agreement allows them to start building a happy and peaceful new le.It came after Prince Andrew was forced to step down from public duties last year after his disastrous Newsnight interview in which he failed to show empathy to the victims of his paedophile pal Jeffrey Epstein.

title: coronavirus getting worse more contagious than sars china
story: Medics are racing to halt a pandemic after it was revealed coronavirus  - which has claimed multiple lives - is more contagious and much harder to detect than SARS.Chinas Health minister Ma Xiaowei revealed the incubation period for the deadly bug can range from one to  days - a far cry from the state reported number of , infections.Mr Xiaowei told face-masked reporters at a press conference today, that the authorities have cranked up efforts to stop the spread of the virus after admitting that they have limited knowledge of how the disease mutates.After the outbreak of the disease we have followed the principles of openness and transparency and have conducted full communication and cooperation with the WHO [World Health Organisation], relevant countries and also Hong Kong, said Mr Xiaowei.We have invited WHO experts to Wuhan to check the situation on the ground. We have provided diagnosis kits to Hong Kong and Macau free of charge.The health minister also revealed Beijing is sharing information with other nations after the US, Thailand, South Korea, Japan, Australia, France all confirmed cases.Chinese president Xi Jinping described the situation as grave on Saturday.On the same day Canada declared a first presumptive confirmed case in a resident who had ed from Wuhan.Health officials in Orange County, Calornia, reported that a third case of the virus had been registered in the US in a traveller from Wuhan, who was in isolation and in good condition.The Lunar New Year holiday, traditionally celebrated by millions of Chinese travelling around the country and abroad to see family, began on Friday but has been severely disrupted by the outbreak.Mr Xiaowei said China would intensy its containment efforts which have so far included transportation and travel curbs and the cancellation of big events.No fatalities have been reported outside China.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate middleton holocaust exhibition photos
story: Aspiring photographer Kate, , snapped them with their families to mark  years since the end of the horrors today.Yvonne Bernstein, , who was hidden in France, is pictured showing her ID card with a J on it to granddaughter Chloe Wright, . And Steven Frank, , who survived several concentration camps, poses with his granddaughters Maggie Fleet, , and Trixie Fleet, , right.Kate says meeting them was a “privilege”.Both portraits were taken at Kensington Palace, with the Duchess painstakingly spending over two hours ensuring they were perfect.Two other survivors — Joan Salter, , and John Hajdu,  — posed for photographers Frederic Aranda and Jillian Edelstein.Kate, who is Royal Photographic Society patron, said: “The harrowing atrocities of the Holocaust, which were caused by the most unthinkable evil, will forever lay heavy in our hearts.“Despite unbelievable trauma at the start of their lives, Yvonne Bernstein and Steven Frank are two of the most le-affirming people that I have had the privilege to meet.“They look back on their experiences with sadness, but also with gratitude that they were some of the lucky few to make it through.“It is vital that their memories are preserved and passed on to future generations, so that what they went through will never be forgotten.“Their stories will stay with me forever. Whilst I have been lucky enough to meet two of the now very few survivors, I recognise not everyone in the future will be able to hear these stories first hand.“I wanted to make the portraits deeply personal to Yvonne and Steven - a celebration of family and the le that they have built since they both arrived in Britain in the s.The project is a collaborative one between the Holocaust Memorial Day Trust, Jewish News and the Royal Photographic Society.Kate and William will today be at the Holocaust Memorial Day ceremony in Westminster.I imagine that she was very nervous, but she tackled it brilliantly.The picture of Steven Frank with his two granddaughters really impressed me because the first thing you notice is the cooking pot on his lap.His mother carried it with her through every concentration camp that they were taken to, and collected small pieces of food in the pot and put water to it made a paste kept her and her son alive.The lighting is very dramatic, it was dramatic times for those people whose only crime is that they were born a Jew.The other picture of Yvonne Bernstein is also beautully composed, and she is showing her granddaughter Chloe her German ID card.Once again Kate has taken her time and got a beautul photograph, using natural light.Quite honestly I think she has done an excellent job. story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: where auschwitz liberation concentration camp
story: During the Holocaust over a million people – the vast majority of them Jews – lost their lives.Auschwitz concentration camp was constructed in the suburbs of the Polish city Oświęcim, near the modern nations southern border, in .The site was already the location of  dilapidated buildings, which had previously housed soldiers and workers.After annexing that region of Poland during the early stages of World War Two, by April  the Nazi regime needed somewhere to house to Polish political prisoners, with local jails full.The majority of local residents were evicted to make way for German citizens, and Jewish workers from Oświęcim were forced to lay the foundations of the camp.A month after plans were approved, the first prisoners arrived at the initial camp, Auschwitz I, and within a year over , people were imprisoned there.When it was complete, it held around , inmates in appallingly cramped conditions, with numbers sometimes rising above ,.Above the gates, like other Nazi death camps, was the famous motto Arbeit macht frei – Work brings freedom.In October , with the German war in the East wreaking terrible loss of le, construction began for a second larger camp, Auschwitz II-Birkenau, in the village of Brzezinka three kilometres way.On the original plans for the huge facility, SS architect Karl Bischoff set the capacity for each cramped barracks at  – this figure was crossed out by hand, and replaced with .It was in Birkenau, which held , prisoners by , that the first gas chamber was made operational in March .This was later followed by several others, where the majority of Auschwitz prisoners were murdered on an industrial scale as the Holocaust plunged horrying depths.In October  a third camp, Auschwitz III, began housing prisoners at Monowitz around seven kilometres from the original site.There were also over  sub-camps in the surrounding areas, creating a vast, heavily-guarded complex enclosed by barbed wire fences and patrolled by thousands of SS troops.The camp was liberated on January , , by the rapidly advancing Soviet troops – the date is now commemorated each year as Holocaust Memorial Day.The Soviet Army liberated the remaining , prisoners from the camps.The sheer scale of mass murder involved in the Holocaust means its impossible to calculate a precise figure.In total, an estimated . million people were sent to Auschwitz – and at least . million of these died.Around % of the dead were Jewish, representing approximately a sixth of all Jews killed in the Holocaust.The rest of the inmates were comprised of Polish and Soviet prisoners, thousands of Romany people and an unknown number imprisoned for being homosexual.When the mass killings were at their peak, up to , Jews were being gassed per day, with the cyanide-based pesticide Zyklon B the weapon of choice.Those not killed in the gas chambers perished from starvation, forced labour and the infectious diseases that spread unchecked through the camps.The quality of le at Auschwitz was appalling – a true hell on earth.When they werent being worked to death, inmates were crammed together in unhygienic, inhumane conditions, and lived with the constant threat of punishment or torture at the hands of the SS guards.Furthermore, prisoners were subjected to degrading, often fatal medical experiments at the hands of twisted doctors such as the notorious Josef Mengele.With the Nazis rapidly losing ground against the Soviet Red Army in the latter stages of the war, Auschwitz was evacuated and much of it demolished.At the start of  the remaining prisoners were forced westwards into a death march, with many thousands perishing in the harsh winter conditions.Since June , Auschwitz has been open as a poignant museum devoted to the memories of those who lost their lives in the camp.Over a million people visit every year, with the exhibitions housed in many of the camps original buildings.Auschwitz has been a protected UNESCO World Cultural Heritage site since , and admission to the grounds of the memorial is free of charge.However, there are fees in place for guided tours and for renting headphone audio guides.Visitors are asked to observe appropriate solemnity and respect – last year, British tourists sparked outrage by posing for inappropriate selfies in the museum.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kevin maguire tories already fretting
story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: Tories already fretting about Superflop Boris Johnsons first weeksOlder Tory heads are unfavourably comparing Boris Johnsons early weeks to the Labour bundle of energy that was Tony Blair here, there and everywhere on his  debutShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  JAN NewsopinionSuperflop’s idle arrogance will transform him into a supervillain" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTroubled Tory MPs fretting he’s Superflop, not Superman, would concern a Prime Minister less arrogant than Boris Johnson. Increasing murmurings on Westminster’s Tory benches about drt and lack of direction betray a creeping nervousness in party ranks – only a month after winning a thumping Parliamentary majority. Friday’s orchestrated celebrations of a Brexit not yet done and Britain remaining in the Single Market and Customs Union during ’s dangerous £billion trade talks will distract momentarily from the growing unease but prove no permanent ersion. Wiser Tory heads worry that Johnson thinks Downing Street is a grander version of London’s City Hall, where as Mayor he spent his time posing for photographs and squandering public money on vanity buses and an unbuilt garden bridge, stealing other people’s credit for the London  Olympics. Older Tory heads compare – unfavourably – Johnson’s early weeks, including a fortnight’s holiday in Mustique, to the Labour bundle of energy that was Tony Blair here, there and everywhere on his  debut. Early impressions count. HS, Huawei, climate emergencies and Whitehall upheaval are splitting a party incapable of remaining united outside election time. Include a slouching economy, an ailing NHS given a plaster instead of the required transfusion and another round of school cuts... and the bleak picture that emerges is nothing like the pretty fiction Johnson painted in December.  Add a dash of resentment over posh weirdo misfit adviser Dominic Cummings’ Mafioso act and the mix is political Kryptonite. This Clark Kent with thinning hair isn’t the character he sold to the electorate. Folk in seats such as Sedgefield, Stoke, Redcar, Grimsby and West Brom are entitled to feel short-changed.

story: NewsFirst picture of girl, , who died in house fire after dad barricaded them in roomGarry Bolton, , died at the scene of the house fire in Hull, while daughter Paige was later pronounced dead in hospital. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBeaming in a woolly hat and clutching a scooter, this is the first picture of a tragic -year-old girl who died following a house fire. Paige was barricaded in a room with dad Garry Bolton, it is believed, as the blaze consumed the property in Hull on Saturday morning. Garry, , was pronounced dead at the scene, while Paige sadly later died in hospital. Floral tributes are today being laid outside their home as friends, family and the community try and come to terms with the devastating deaths. Have you been affected by this story  Email webnews@mirror It in the second tragedy to rock the family as Paigeaposs twin, Ethan, died in . A grief-stricken friend said: Paige was a twin and they lost the other twin at birth. They were born prematurely. Heartbroken neighbours have aslo told of their shock at the death of the devoted single father and his daughter. The fire is believed to have been started in a bedroom and neighbours said they saw smoke coming from a top floor window.  Carl Goodfellow, , was one of the first on the scene to try to rescue the stricken pair. He said: Itaposs just a tragic event. He was devoted to his daughter, weaposd see him taking her to school every day and weaposd say hello but that was it really. I heard shouting this morning and saw smoke coming from the upstairs window. I tried to break the door down but it was too strong. I was banging on the door and shouting to get their attention, but it was to no avail sadly.  My heart just goes out to the immediate family who have to deal with this tragic incident. The whole street is in shock, itaposs a quiet, close-knit community and you just donapost expect something like this to happen. A nearby resident, who did not want to be named, said: It just makes it a double tragedy. Everybody on this street knows each other, at least to speak to. His we was so overjoyed they were expecting babies and it really affected her when she lost her son. They felt really lucky that the daughter had pulled through, but to lose her in these circumstances just makes it doubly heartbreaking.  I was woken up this morning lots of banging and shouting. I saw them pull the little girl out and lay her on a green sheet trying to do CPR. I kept thinking please god let that poor little girl live. Iaposm just numb, Iaposm in a real state of shock. Next door neighbours climbed over a six foot fence to try to alert the man and his daughter to the fire. Another neighbour, who did not want to be named, said the man who died in the fire was a devoted single father who had quit work to be a full-time dad after his marriage broke up.  He said: I heard shouting and banging this morning so went to have a look. I climbed over the fence that separates our gardens and tried banging on the door as loud as I could. The Fire Brigade turned up within minutes and took over, but they couldnapost get them out in time sadly. We would say hello in the street and weaposd swap Christmas cards, but that was it. He kept himself to himself, he was never any trouble.  He gave up work to take care of her full-time. He was a hard-working single dad. Humberside Police today said they were continuing to support the pairaposs family. In a statement, Chief Superintendent Darren Downs said: We know that this has also had an impact on the wider community, so please feel free to speak to our officers in the areayou have any queries or concerns.  There is also support available from a number of local agencies and charities for anyone who has been affected by the incident and needs someone to talk to. Investigations into this kind of incident are very complex and take time to complete, so itaposs unlikely that we will be able to provide any further details about the incident until early next week. He asked people to avoid speculating about the circumstances of the fire in the statement. A post-mortem examination is being carried today, the force added, and another is scheduled to be carried out on Paige next week. A statement by Humberside Police yesterday said: Emergency services are currently at the scene of a fire at a house on Wensley Avenue in Hull. Humberside Fire and Rescue, ambulance and police were called at .am today to reports of a fire at a house. Emergency services worked to extinguish the fire and get the occupants out of the building.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe daughter of an -year-old man forced to wait  hours for a bed after being rushed to hospital, said it was a worrying sign for the struggling NHS. Terry Koerber, who lives alone, was left unable to walk after his knee gave way, but on arriving at Leicester Royal Infirmary he found an AE full of patients on trolleys. The pensioner had to wait  minutes in the ambulance outside before waiting even longer for an X-ray and a bed, which he finally got at am, having arrived at pm. His daughter Karen Stone said of the experience: It was terrible – the system is rubbish, reports LeicestershireLive. Leicester hospitals said there was exceptional demand for beds on the day in question, and apologised to Mr Koerber. The great-granddadaposs we of  years, Beryl, is in a care home and so he lives alone in Leicester, needing his mobility to remain independent. Mr Koerber collapsed on Boxing Day and his daughter, who stayed with him for part of his hospital ordeal, said he wasnapost in good shape prior to the accident. Karen, , said she had gone round to her dadaposs house twice to help out before he collapsed on December . “The next morning I went back and he had no mobility at all, which is not usual for my dad – he’s very active.” At around am, Karen called for a non-emergency ambulance and found seven other ambulances in front of them. At am on Friday, December , Karen called the NHS for a non-emergency ambulance to take her father to hospital. We just waited there for an hour-and-a-half – all this time the ambulance couldn’t go anywhere , of course, she explained. “We were there that long they asked uswe wanted a cup of tea and a biscuit. “My dad was in pain and he’d only had paracetamol at home and it wasn’t having much of an effect. “I appreciate there were people in more need of urgent care but it’s worrying the NHS is struggling so much and that the response from staff seemed to be that it wasn’t that uncommon,” she continued. At about .pm Mr Koerber was taken into a bay in the hospital and had some tests done and he was sent for an x-ray. Karen, of Barrow upon Soar, near  Loughborough, said it took so long for the X-ray to be done she thinks they had forgotten us. “After the x-ray the bay we had been in was being used so they put dad in a corridor with other people on trolleys.” Karen waited in the corridor with her father until .pm, assuming he given a bed imminently, particularly considering he had not slept the night before due to knee pains. But at .am the next day Mr Koerber called his daughter to say he was still on the trolley. Karen said: “He was absolutely exhausted. It was terrible – the system is rubbish.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo grieving mums are demanding answers over the mystery deaths of their sons they believe were murdered. Norah Connelly and  Stephanie Bonner were strangers when their sons Jonathan and Rhys died within days of each other in Glasgow last year, but theyaposve joined forces to put pressure on the police. The devastated women believe their boys could have met violent ends but are frustrated the police have never declared their deaths as murders. They fear the cases have been pushed down the pecking order and could be eventually forgotten, reports the Daily Record. “Our sons’ killers are out there and people know who and why. Don’t let something like this happen to you. Help us get justice for our boys, said Norah and Stephanie in a joint statement. Nineteen-year-old Rhysapos body was found half naked on August  after disappeared from the Balanark area of Glasgow on July . The Celtic fan had told his mum he going to to watch a football match with his dad but he never turned up. Family and friends launched a social media campaign to find the teenager before he was found in marsh land near the village of Gartloch. While Jonathan, a twin with learning dficulties, had been missing a week when his body was found in the water at Spiers Wharf on July . The -year-old had injuries to his head and body, and had gone missing after going into the town centre to speak to his employers about why his wages had not been paid.  The two mums both believe the initial missing persons reports were not taken seriously by police and think vital evidence may have been lost. Family members instead carried out their own investigations in a desperate bid to try and get some answers. “I just need to know what happened to my boy, said mum-of-five Stephanie. He was . I have no doubt my son was murdered. I need answers. We all miss him so much.” Norah, who has two daughters, said: “Whoever put Johnny in that canal did it to make it look like a suicide. My son would never have left me alone. Le is empty for us all now. I know Johnny was assaulted before he died. I will never give up searching for answers.” She waited two days after he disappeared before contacting police and said from that moment on she felt asher le has been destroyed.  Stephanie said: “I knew as only a mother would that something terrible had happened to Rhys. I put it on Facebook askinganyone had seen him. I heard he was seen with an older woman and we told the police this but they did nothing so me and my sister went to her house and she denied even knowing Rhys. “It took the police two weeks to search where his body was found and, even months later, I’m still not sure of the exact location but he was found half-naked, with his clothes about  yards away. “His baseball cap was discovered in a common stair and had been washed. The shorts he was wearing that day have never been found. “They didn’t have any forensics out they just put him in a van and took him away. They said they wouldn’t get any forensics due to theof time. It took them seven weeks to formally identy him.” Stephanie said her own probed uncovered CCTV of her tragic son with a woman but she said police took days to check the footage despite her pleas.  She said: “During those seven weeks, I still kept praying it wasn’t him but I knew deep down. I knew my boy was gone. I have prayed for justice, for answers. This has broken my family. It has consumed my le. I promised Rhys when he was lying in his coffin I would get answers for him and I would get justice. It’s all I can do for my son. We’re all shattered.” “Rhys was a cheeky but loveable teenager with his whole le ahead. His disappearance and death should have been taken more seriously. I feel let down by the police. Nobody from Police Scotland has been helping me. I’ve been forced to seek the answers myself. “It’s soul destroying. I can’t let this happen to anyone . My boy, our boys, deserve more. I beg anyone who may have information to speak to the police or call in anonymously. “Someone must know what happened to my son. His brothers and sisters miss him – we all do.” Norah said she is clinging to the hope an appeal by police for witnesses will unlock vital information in the hunt for her Johnny’s attackers. “It’s taken all this time for police to put out an appeal. When Johnny went missing and his body was found, my ex-husband made a video retracing his steps, she continued.  “They had Johnny on CCTV walking until he got to the underpass at Spiers Wharf. Johnny had learning dficulties and no sense of danger. If someone spoke to him, he’d chat back not realisinghe was in danger. “It breaks my heart to think my boy would be alive todayhe’d been paid his wages when he should have been. He wouldn’t have gone into town, he’d have stayed local and met up with his friends. “The police don’t know how he ended up in the water but whoever attacked him did it to make it look like suicide. We still don’t know how Johnny died. He’d been in the water too long. Evidence was lost. “The police weren’t helping which is why we put out videos and put up information and appeals on social media. “Johnny was a family man. We were very close. His twin sister, Norah, and his big sister Michelle miss him so much – his dad as well. None of us can have peace until we know what happened to him.

title: kate middletons powerful photo portraits
story: NewsKate Middletons powerful photo portraits of "le affirming" Holocaust survivorsThe Duchess of Cambridge Kate Middleton took part in a project photographing two Holocaust survivors to mark the th anniversary of the liberation of Nazi concentration campsShareCommentsByRichard Palmer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsKate Middleton was one of several people who photographed Holocaust survivors and their families for the th anniversary of the liberation of Nazi concentration camps " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge has captured the inner strength of Holocaust survivors in photographs to mark the th anniversary of the liberation of Nazi concentration camps.   She has made it her mission to help break the cycle of damaged children becoming damaged adults in Britain but in this new photographic project Kate encountered grandparents who had endured the most horric of childhood traumas and come through incredible adversity to live fulfilled lives. Inspired by the story of Anne Frank and the pictures of th century Dutch artist Johannes Vermeer, the future Queen, one of several photographers involved in the project, took portraits of two survivors with their children and grandchildren and described them as “two of the most le-affirming people that I have had the privilege to meet”.   Each of the portraits, which will be published on Monday to mark Holocaust Memorial Day, depicts the special connection between a survivor and younger relatives carrying their legacy. They are designed to encourage everyone in Britain to perpetuate and share the memory of the horrors inflicted by the Nazis. One of Kate’s portraits was of -year-old Steven Frank, originally from Amsterdam, who survived multiple concentration camps as a child. He is pictured alongside his granddaughters Maggie and Trixie Fleet, aged  and .  Her other portrait is of -year-old Yvonne Bernstein, originally from Germany, who was a hidden child in France throughout most of the Holocaust. She is pictured with her -year-old granddaughter Chloe Wright. Kate, , who is patron of the Royal Photographic Society and a keen amateur snapper, said: The harrowing atrocities of the Holocaust, which were caused by the most unthinkable evil, will forever lay heavy in our hearts. Yet it is so often through the most unimaginable adversity that the most remarkable people flourish. Despite unbelievable trauma at the start of their lives, Yvonne Bernstein and Steven Frank are two of the most le-affirming people that I have had the privilege to meet. They look back on their experiences with sadness, but also with gratitude that they were some of the lucky few to make it through. Their stories will stay with me forever. Whilst I have been lucky enough to meet two of the now very few survivors, I recognise not everyone in the future will be able to hear these stories first hand. It is vital that their memories are preserved and passed on to future generations, so that what they went through will never be forgotten.  One of the most moving accounts I read as a young girl was The Diary of Anne Frank, which tells a very personal reflection of le under Nazi occupation from a childaposs perspective. Her sensitive and intimate interpretation of the horrors of the time was one of the underlying inspirations behind the images. I wanted to make the portraits deeply personal to Yvonne and Steven - a celebration of family and the le that they have built since they both arrived in Britain in the s. The families brought items of personal signicance with them which are included in the photographs. It was a true honour to have been asked to participate in this project and I hope in some way Yvonne and Stevenaposs memories will be kept alive as they pass the baton to the next generation. The Duchess, a history of art graduate, said her photographic style in these portraits was inspired by Vermeer, whose domestic interior scenes of middle class le display a signature pearly light and draw the eye into the picture using carefully placed objects. Her photo of Yvonne features her German ID card, dated March , , which has a letter ‘J’ for Jew stamped on it. There is also a treasured brooch, bought for Yvonne by her daughter. It was made by the jewellery firm founded by her great-grandfather before it was taken over by the Nazis. Steven and his granddaughters included particularly poignant items in his portrait by Kate. They included a pan which his mother kept with them to cook extra morsels of food throughout their time in the camps, and a tomato from his garden. When Steven was in the Theresienstadt camp as a child, he helped another prisoner grow tomatoes. “He had picked out the pips from rotten tomatoes and grew his own. I became his little helper, watering these tomatoes,” Steven said. “He showed me how to pick out the side shoots so they grow straight, then when he was sent off to a camp in Poland, he asked me to look after his plants. “I was so proud to be asked - I was only eight years old. Since the war I have grown tomatoes at home in the greenhouse and every time I water them I think of this man. I don’t even know his name. I still feel  years on that I’m watering his tomato plants for him. When the tomatoes are out now the grandchildren come over and help to pick them.” The portraits will be part of a new exhibition which will open later this year, bringing together  powerful images of survivors and their family members to mark  years since the end of the Holocaust.  Two other portraits, by distinguished photographers Jillian Edelstein and Frederic Aranda, are released today to announce the project - a collaboration between the Holocaust Memorial Day Trust, Jewish News, and the Royal Photographic Society. Other images featuring in the exhibition will be taken by fellows of the Royal Photographic Society. In a photograph by Frederic Aranda, Joan Salter, , who fled the Nazis as a young child, appears with her husband Martin and her daughter Shelley. John Hajdu, , who survived the Budapest Ghetto, is in a portrait with his four-year-old grandson Zac photographed by Jillian Edelstein.

According to a former confidante of the -year-old yoga teacher, Doria silently influenced the shocking choice by Meghan and Prince Harry. In a deal which will see them spend a majority of their time in Canada with son Archie, they will not use their HRH titles, will no longer formally represent the Queen and will not receive public funds for royal duties. In addition they will repay £.million used to do refurbish  Frogmore Cottage – the Windsor home they will continue to use when in the UK. The confidante told Mail Online that Doria had grown close to Harry who described her as amazing shortly after the couple got engaged. They said they believe she has most definitely been giving the couple advice during the current drama. They said: When Meghan and Harry announced they were walking away from their jobs as Royals to be financially independent, it immediately smacked of Doria. Being financially independent has always been important to her. Harry in particular turns to herfor advice. She is like the Queen – she never complains and never explains.  Doria has a great warmth. Sheaposs a brilliant cook and is very motherly, but she isnapost someone who seeks attention, and for Harry her discretion and silence mean the world. Meghan has always trusted her completely but she has become a rock to Harry who, of course, lost his own mother so young. Sheaposs laid-back, and people see her nose ring and dreadlocks which are cool – but make no mistake, she has a core of steel. Underestimate her at your peril. Doria, who lives in Los Angeles,  has kept a dignied silence about her daughter while Meghanaposs estranged dad Thomas Markle has openly spoken about his relationship with her.  In addition his daughter Samantha Markle has been highly critical of her half-sibling even before Meghan fell out with her dad. Doria has always been someone who values her privacy and no more so than now, the confidante said. But she has been back and forth for the last few weeks. And when sheaposs not with them, she is on the phone constantly. On Saturday Thomas said his final wish is to be reunited with Meghan – and he will never give up trying.

Warda Mahamud is embroiled in a row with her local authority about the shocking state of her facilities. She claims her children were forced to have baths in the lounge because of the stinking condition of their washroom. According to Warda, Birmingham City Council sub-contractors exposed pipework when they visited her flat in .They promised tothe next day but have not been back since, reports BirminghamLive.The authority insisted it had tried to complete the work but had been refused access to the property - something Warda denied. She said the lights had broken in the bathroom due to leaking water and, as she used the toilet, yellow, sticky liquid dripped onto her from above. Tragically, Warda lost her eldest son to cancer shortly after moving into the address in September . She told BirminghamLive: The other day my child was running up and down, I forgot to close the door, he went inside.  I had to drag him out of there, he was so dirty. The children have to take a bath in the living room because the bathroom stinks. The water thataposs falling down isnapost clean, itaposs yellowish and sticky. They [the council] took the wall off where the water was leaking from, they fixed my heater, they saw the condition of the flat.They said: aposWeaposll come back by tomorrowapos. But they havenapost been back since - and that was in about the September of . She said she first noticed the leaking ceiling in the bathroom when she moved in but, as her son was ill, she didnapost complain to the council until after his death early in . She added: I wasnapost paying attention to it as I was in and out of hospital with him because he was having treatment.  My head was all over the place. I remember my son every day in this flat. I saw him die in this flat. After his death, I explained to the council that there was damp and the wallpaper was falling off. She said council workers removed the wall from the bathroom and fixed her heating in September , but the wall had not been replaced.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum went on a diet so she could donate a kidney to her son and save his le. Anne Cooney, , shed the pounds to ensure she was in the best possible health before the op. Her son Adam, , was diagnosed in  with rare condition IgA vasculitis, which led to chronic kidney disease. Medics gave him two options, a transplant or dialysis. And after a series of tests Anne was told she was a perfect match. Adam was not sure he wanted his mum to go through the procedure. “I didn’t want my mum to die because of my transplant” he said. “We went to a meeting with a surgeon, who tells you everything that can go wrong. “I thought ‘maybe I’m not going to bother with dialysis or a transplant. I’ve done my thing, I’ve had a nice le’.” But Anne, from Sale, Greater Manchester, insisted on going under the kne.  “As a mum you do what you can for your children to make their le easier and it just seemed the right thing to do. I obviously got apprehensive before the operation. Their exhaustion meant they overslept and got left behind, awaking to “dead silence”.The bear was in fact a scout arriving ahead of the advancing Soviets who,  days later, would free Auschwitz and those clinging to le there. The -year-old, one of the few who was in Auschwitz for its liberation  years ago today, recalls this first moment of hope with a dazzling, lipsticked smile. She says: “We saw a huge creature in fur with icicles hanging from him, who, before it was daylight, looked like a bear. “When it came closer it turned out it was a Russian scout in a big Russian hat. He couldn’t speak our language. The Russians didn’t know about the camps, the gassing, that we were Jewish. But he looked at us, and knew we were victims.” Soberly, she reflects on the fact the fates of she and her playmate, the diarist Anne Frank, just one month younger, could so easily have swapped. Anne and her older sister Margot, who posthumously, became her famous step-sisters when her widowed mother married their widower father, Otto, were instead marched to Bergen-Bn where they died before British troops could free them three months later. “If Anne and Margot had not gone on that march, they’d have survived,” she insists, quietly. “We overslept, and that saved our le. Our positions could have changed easily.” Eva’s family and the Franks met in Amsterdam, where both fled to escape persecution. The girls would play on the street.  Eva remembers the day “chatterbox” Anne showed off the diary Otto had given her for her th birthday. “I remember her being so happy,” she smiles. “She liked writing so much, she loved telling stories.” Soon afterwards, the Franks went into hiding, and so did Eva’s family, who were eventually betrayed, and transported in May, . The Franks were discovered in September. Both families ended up in Auschwitz, but didn’t meet. Eva’s last memory of Anne is of the bubbly girl brandishing the diary which would, published by her father after the war, make her world-famous. Eva survived selection for the gas chambers because her mother gave her a wide-brimmed hat to hide her youth. “That was the first miracle,” she says. Every detail of Auschwitz remains crystal clear. “The filth, the dirt, no toilets. If they caught you sitting on a bucket you would be beaten. The indignity,” she recalls, sitting in her incongruously cosy North London flat. “The lice. We became covered in scabs and boils. And the starvation,” she says. “The cup of liquid in the morning, the chunk of bread at night.” Eva describes the growing sense of chaos in December . “We realised the Nazis were nervous,” she says. “A lot of the guards ran away.”  One night they announced they’d be leaving on a march, and Birkenau, the women’s sub-camp, was to be burned. It wasn’t, and they were left behind. “The camp was deserted, no dogs barking. There was dead silence,” Eva explains. There were around  ­prisoners left in Birkenau, she believes, and the same in the men’s camp. Eva remembers no other children. The only food was dregs. “There was a small pond and we hacked the ice to get water,” says Eva. Deaths were daily. The memory that terrorised Eva for years was moving bodies. “We had to heap them up. I tried to close their eyelids, but they were frozen,” she says. When the Soviets arrived she was joyful because she longed for food. “It was too soon to feel any joy of survival,” she says. “They gave us metal bowls of cabbage soup with strong bacon fat. We ate, and ate, and ate.”  The eating after months of starvation led to tragedy. “In the morning there were dead people,” Eva says. In the men’s camp, she saw Otto Frank. “He looked terrible,” Eva recalls. “He was asking, ‘Have you seen my girls ’” Two weeks later, the Soviets started transporting them to Odessa, now in Ukraine. The troops gave them their unorms for warmth – Eva kept hers for years. And as the women gained weight, they provided bras, she giggles. “It made me feel human, like a woman again,” she says. One night, the soldiers struck up music. “They showed me how to dance,” she says. “I began to feel like myself again.” In , she was to be reunited with some of them in Russia. But it was to be many years before she found happiness. Learning her father and brother, Erich and Heinz, had died left her depressed, and she considered suicide.

title: baby elephant left covered faeces
story: NewsPoor baby elephant learns the perils of walking a little too close to mumA photographer caught the moment a mother elephant in Zimbabwes Mana Pools National Park defecated on its babys head - but theres more to this ritual than you thinkShareCommentsByLucy Skoulding:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsA photographer managed to capture the moment the mother elephant pooped on her little one " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOne little baby elephant in Zimbabwe got a bit too close to its mother - and it didnapost end well. A wildle photographer captured the exact moment that a mother elephant left faeces on its babyaposs head. The photographer watched the series of events unfold in the Mana Pools National Park in Zimbabwe. But whataposs not initially obvious is the fact thereaposs more to this action than meets the eye - and according to officials, the act actually helps the younger giants develop a strong immune system. Jens Cullman, a photographer, said: What I’ve heard is that when the baby get dung on it, it helps boost the baby’s immune system and maybe it’s some kind of bonding with the mother as well. I got photos of the calf looking towards me and then it gets up and the mum turns around and the calf follows her and then she drops her dung on him. The photos were exciting for me, I have to admit. Friends and family I’ve shown them to think they’re hilarious. Everyone was just ‘wow wow wow’.  So, in what seems like a very counterproductive move, poo actually helps the baby elephantaposs immune system. Photographer Jens added that these photos have a far more serious aspect to them than the dung incident. He said the mother elephant was skinny because of a bad dry season in the park, a lot of elephants and other animals having reportedly died or suffered. Jens said: In Mana Pools this year it was very dry and a lot of animals suffered.The mother was a very skinny elephant as well. A lot of elephants and baby elephants died because of the drought. Jens added that he had to stop the car to snap a photo when she saw the adorable baby elephant.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFrance has banned the use of a controversial tear gas grenade that has been blamed for blowing off the fingers and hands of anti-government protestors. Interior Minister Christophe Castaner said the GLI-F cannister, which is described a ‘weapon of war’ in field manuals would no longer be issued to law and order officials. Mr Castaner on Sunday told France  television that too many demonstrators had been seriously injured. This is the reason I think we have to remove the GLI-F,’ said Mr Castaner, who said this would happen immediately. There have been continual disturbances on the streets of major French cities including Paris for more than a year as thousands protest against Emmanuel Macron’s government. The latest demonstrations are against pension reforms, but the Yellow Vest movement has also been consistently on the streets since November . Named after their distinctive fluorescent motoring jackets, the Vests started out protesting against rising fuel prices but now want a reform of the entire Fth Republic. Many of the Vests have been hit by the GLI-F, which is made up of teargas and an explosive charge of  grams of TNT. Riot squad officers frequently fire hundreds of rounds of the grenades on to crowds, in an attempt to control them. Up until now, France has been the only European country to deploy the GLI-F, which cause a deafening blast and can easily maim those hit. In February last year, a protester picked up one of the grenades outside the National Assembly, France’s Parliament in Paris, and lost four fingers. A man also had his hand torn off by one of the grenades in Bordeaux in December .  In May , the OF F – another type of grenade which was frequently used by French police – was banned after it was linked to the death of botanist Rémi Fraisse. Mr Fraise, who was also an environmental campaign, died at the age of  after one of the stun grenades was fired at him by police during a protest against the building of a dam near Toulouse. In November, a -year-old police brigadier received a two months suspended prison sentence for throwing part of a broken paving stone at Yellow Vest protesters in Paris.  In the first full-blown prosecution against the forces of law and order held in relation to the movement, the officer was solely identied only as officer A. Other Yellow Vests have lost their eyes after being hit by rubber aposdefensive bulletsapos.

title: one worlds busiest airports turns
story: NewsOne of worlds busiest airports turns into ghost town after coronavirus panicBeijing International Airport was almost deserted yesterday evening as chilling photos taken by a passenger show - Suzan Tokdemir, , was travelling into the capital city from Hong KongShareCommentsByChiara Fiorillo:,  JAN NewsBeijing International Airport looked almost deserted yesterday evening " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOne of the worldaposs busiest airports has turned into a ghost town as passengers stay away amid coronavirus fears. Beijing International Airport was almost completely deserted yesterday evening, as shown by chilling photos taken by a passenger. Suzan Tokdemir, , took the pictures after travelling on an almost-empty flight into the Chinese capital city from Hong Kong. In one photo, which Suzan took on-board the Hong Kong Airlines flight, two members of the cabin crew can be seen wearing clinical masks over their mouths while they serve refreshments from the trolley. Another photo shows only three people outside the airport in a space that is usually very crowded. The airport in the Chinese capital city has ranked second-busiest airport in the world every year since  and usually sees between  and  million passengers pass through it a year. Suzan, who teaches English at an international middle school in Beijing, said: It was quite eerie. Itaposs not what youaposd expect at Beijing Airport. It took me  minutes from getting off the plane to standing outside the front of the airport - that included collecting my luggage, passport check, fingerprint scan, everything. On the flight, there were only about  passengers. I looked around as was getting off the plane, and I estimated there canapost have been much more than  people. It was one of the big planes, with eight seats across in a row, but they put us all at the back of the plane - the front half of the plane was completely empty.  All the flight attendants were masked, and most of the passengers were too. They took them off to eat the food and then put them straight back on. Before we got off, they came round and disinfected the plane, and there was an announcement telling people to declare any symptoms they might have, Suzan added. Suzan, who left Phuket, Thailand on Friday morning, and flew back to Beijing via Bangkok and Hong Kong, said it was spooky to see the numbers dwindle on each of her connecting flights. Even at Hong Kong airport, almost everyone was masked, she said. At Beijing International Airport, we had to keep taking our masks off, so that our faces could be identied - which sort of defeats the point.  She added that even the motorway in Beijing was empty, saying: Usually you can hardly move on the motorway. The coronavirus has emptied Beijing. I had hired a driver to take me home, and he got stopped by masked police on the way back and had his temperature checked. It was really spooky, it was like something out of a sci-fi movie, said Suzan.

title: post mortem exams completed after
story: NewsPost-mortem exams completed after three children found dead in house in DublinPolice said no arrests have been made and they are not looking for anyone  in relation to the incident, but investigations on the circumstances around the deaths are ongoingShareCommentsByBrynmor PattisonChiara Fiorillo:,  JAN NewsThe children - Conor, nine, Darragh, seven and Carla, three - with their father Andrew McGinley" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPost-mortem examinations on the bodies of three children found dead in a house have been completed. But police said the interim results are not being published for operational reasons and further toxicology results are still awaited.The bodies of Conor, nine, Darragh, seven, and Carla, three, were discovered at a house at Parson’s Court in Newcastle village, Dublin, on January , the Irish Mirror reports.They were then removed from the semi-detached home by ambulance at around am on Saturday. The autopsies were carried out by Assistant State Pathologist Margot Bolster at the Dublin City Morgue yesterday evening. The house at Parsonaposs Court, Newcastle, in the south-west of the city, remains sealed off for examinations by the Garda Technical Bureau.  Police said a family liaison officer was in contact with their father Andrew McGinley and the extended family. A woman, thought to be the childrenaposs mother, continues to receive medical treatment at Tallaght University Hospital. Officers believe the children were living with their mother at the property in the quiet cul de sac at the time of the incident.  A note reading “Don’t go upstairs... call ” was reportedly found on a window sill at the house. A special Mass was held yesterday morning at St Finian’s Church, where parish priest Fr Kevin Doherty said the community’s hearts were broken. The childrenaposs devastated father Andrew McGinley also yesterday released a picture of himself with his children through the gardai.

title: callachan aiming to end below par east end record with dark blues
story: East End Park is a venue Ross Callachan is no stranger to.In his six years in the Raith Rovers first-team, he took part in the Fe derby four times, twice in Dunfermline.On neither occasion, however, was the -year-old able to end up on the winning side.But Callachan is hoping to change all that tonight when he heads there as a Dundee player after joining on loan until the end of the season from St Johnstone last week.The Pars are on a poor run of form themselves, losing their last five in the league.However, Callachan insists that counts for nothing and all the Dark Blues can focus on is doing what’s required to earn all three points after the disappointment of exiting the cup to Motherwell in his debut last weekend.“I’ve played them a few times home and away but it’s always tough going to East End,” he said.“They’ll be looking to win, losing their last five games, so I think it’s a must-win for both teams.“It was disappointing to be out of the cup but at least we can focus on the league now.“We have  games left until the end of the season so, hopefully, we can go and push for the play-offs.”Callachan is realistic, however, and knows the pitfalls of the Championship from his time at Raith.With just four points separating Dundee in fourth and the Fers in fth, he hopes to draw on all his experience to help the Dee in this one and every game after.“It’s very tough. I think in this league teams can be inconsistent and, probably, Dundee have been like that themselves throughout this season,” he added.“Hopefully, I can come and help that. I’ve been in the league before with Raith and in the play-offs, too. I’ve been there and done it all before.”Although keen to kick on and help the Dark Blues this term, Callachan is just happy to be playing again after enduring a long spell out of the team at Saints.He only made four appearances for the Perth men this season, the last coming in September, and is enjoying feeling wanted again.“I’m hungry to play, do well and help the team,” he said defiantly.“I want to get games under my belt because it was frustrating at St Johnstone.“You’re sitting in the stands and you feel you can help the team but the manager thought otherwise.“I’m just happy somebody wants me here and I feel like I’ve fitted in right away.“Hopefully, I can go and play and show what I can do.“The initial attraction was Dundee were interested in me. My head was turned right away.“Obviously, not playing at St Johnstone made me want to come here.“The plan is to help the club get to where it wants to be, back in the Premiership.“We’re in the play-off spots now so, hopefully, we push and climb up to second.“Dundee United are going to win the league so the main thing for us is getting to the play-offs and going up that way.“We want to finish as high as possible.”Playing alongside and learning from quality players like Graham Dorrans is another reason why Callachan was happy to make the switch up the A, across Tayside.And he was delighted to see his team-mate sign a new deal this week.“He’s, obviously, played at a right high level and you can tell he’s a good player who can help the team.“Him signing a new deal can only be good for us.“It’s good for everyone we have that competition.“It’s good for the club and for the boys, competition is always good.”

title: exclusive hibs kid fraser murray set for dundee loan
story: Hibs youngster Fraser Murray is set to join Dundee on loan until the end of the season, Tele Sport can exclusively reveal.The -year-old midfielder is a product of the Hibees academy set-up and has made  appearances for their first team.The Easter Road club are keen for him to get more game-time under his belt and hope a switch to Dens Park will offer that.The Dark Blues hope to have the deal sewn up this week in time for Saturday’s trip to Morton.Meanwhile, club-mate Sean Mackie has ed to Hibs after picking up an injury in his temporary spell on Tayside.

title: major shake up of education in dundee to be debated as plans to merge craigie high and braeview academy unveiled
story: A massive shake-up of education provision in Dundee has been unveiled by council leader John Alexander .The far-reaching proposals brought forward by Mr Alexander and his administration would see:Subject to consultation, a new £ million superschool, merging pupils from Braeview and Craigie, could be built at the former St Saviour#s High with a projected opening of .Braeview was ravaged by fire in September . The blaze was described in council reports as #catastrophic# with #around % of teaching rooms signicantly damaged#.Mr Alexander said: #There is a real need for improvement in the east of the city.#We have spent £m since  and invested in new schools and that is not including the £m spent on existing schools.#But we cannot afford to build two brand new schools.#The plan,we get agreement for a full consultation, is to merge Craigie and Braeview Academy.#We are looking at what happened in Fe after a fire when there was a merger with a college. We see this as the way and Dundee and Angus College would be involved in taking this forward, with enhanced provision.#Both these schools are grade C in terms of quality and both need upgrading but looking at the financial elements we cannot afford it.#The priority is in the east and we cannot have Braeview Academy people sitting in portable cabins.#Mr Alexander, a former pupil of St Saviour#s High School, outlined how #vocational partnerships# between Braeview and Michelin would be continued at the new campus at Drumgeith Road.He added that a joint project between Dundee City Council and Dundee and Angus College would be launched to accommodate people with additional support needs.Mr Alexander said: #I spoke with three executives from Michelin and we are really focused on making things work.#The consultation,approved by committee on Monday, would start on February  and run until the end of March. We have to be honest with the public and we want the feedback from parents.#This is the very start of the process. And as a parent your focus is absolutely on what is in the best interests of your children.#Part of the consultation process will be looking at proposals for Craigiebarns to be part of the catchment area for Grove. That would take effect from August , so again there is a lead in time to give people the time to give feedback.#He told how boundaries are to be changed to help accommodate the uneven mix of schools which are under capacity and those which are over capacity both in primary and secondary.Turning his attention to the over side of the city, Mr Alexander said: #The re-alignment catchment areas for Harris Academy would remove Invergowrie and they would go to school in Perth.#Meanwhile, the future of a  much-vaunted new primary is also hanging in the balance — at least in the short-term.The council leader hinted that he understood that was likely to be a controversial decision.#We have also had a very detailed analysis of how many pupils in the area of Western Gateway and which schools they go to,# Mr Alexander continued.#There are  pupils on site , but we need to address the other issues with the priority being at the east end of the city, so Western Gateway is not a priority. This is not the time to do it and we cannot construct a primary school on the basis of  pupils.#We are not saying no to the school, but it is just not the right time now. title: whirlwind year coming together for utds harkes
story: Midfielder Ian Harkes has had a whirlwind  months at Dundee United but it’s all coming together for the American.The midfielder signed up at Tannadice as a relative unknown last January # but quickly made a first-team spot his own.The dream of promotion had to wait at the first time of asking as the Tangerines were beaten in the Premiership play-off by St Mirren in May.Fast forward eight months and Harkes is nearing his th appearance for United, has helped his side to a -point lead at the top of the Championship and has been joined in Scotland by fiancee Sarah Teegarden after she signed for Celtic.He also found the net in the Dundee derby in August, scoring United#s fth goal as they romped home to a - victory .Harkes told the Tele: “It hasn’t felt like a year, it’s gone so quickly.“I have enjoyed it at Dundee United and in the city and it’s been a big year of growth for me in my game.“This league has challenged me to increase fitness levels and the rate at which I play. It’s been a great challenge.“The time on the ball you get is the big dference. In the States you get a bit more. vw, px"  “Technically the leagues might be dferent but you are constantly pressing, moving and getting about the pitch.“That brings more demand on the physical side of the game. I have enjoyed that, though.“I think it’s added to my game. I did know what it was about before coming over but getting thrown right into it a year ago helped me out a lot.“I’ve had to adapt quite a lot.”Helping him adjust has been the arrival of fiancee Sarah after she signed as part of Celtic’s new professional ladies set-up .“She is excited to be over here,” Harkes added.“She has played for some really good teams and it’s exciting Celtic are getting up and running full-time.“Hopefully, it goes well for her there and it is nice to have her over here and playing.“With both of us footballers, we have been in dferent places usually but she came over here in August or September to train with them so she has been here a while.“That’s been nice and to get that opportunity at Celtic is huge for her career.”And Harkes would be delighted to join her as a top-flight professional later this year as the Tangerines go for the title, racing clear of the chasing Championship pack.Ahead of tomorrow’s clash with Greenock Morton, the midfielder, though, is aware that taking their foot off the pedal isn’t an option.“We don’t ever want to become complacent,” Harkes stressed.“We are in a good spot in the league but you never want to let that drop. Each game is tough in this league and we need to approach every one the same way.“Now we have separated ourselves from the rest of the league we have to keep it going.“Approach every game right and build on that lead.”That includes ignoring Tuesday night’s big cup replay against Hibs at Easter Road.“Tuesday is a big challenge but we have to focus tomorrow first,# he said.“Hopefully, we can get some good momentum and confidence to take into the replay but we know it will be tough.“Morton will come here tomorrow aiming to take points off us.”When United and Morton met in August, the Tangerines took the three points, putting six goals past a despondent Danny Rogers in the opposition goal .On the cup-tie, Harkes added: “Hibs were a good challenge for us last week.“It was maybe a chance missed for us being at home but I think we fought back well into the game.“Hopefully,we can start better than them on Tuesday then we’ll give them a run.“You could see when we settled into the game you could see we played well but we’ll need to do that from the start.“Morton comes first, though.”

title: charity achieves success in north east housing scheme
story: A project aimed at combating homelessness has achieved “signicant” early success, a charity boss has said.The Housing First scheme launched last April in six parts of Scotland – including in the city and Aberdeenshire.Statistics published last October show more than seven people are recorded as homeless in the Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire area each day.The idea of the scheme is to reduce that figure by giving homeless people tenancies and providing them with extra support as long as they need it.New figures provided by the Aberdeen Cyrenians charity to the Evening Express show the scheme has provided homes to  people in the north-east.The participation rate – the figure that measures how many days service users have complied with their tenancies – is %.It has been so successful that Cyrenians, which is leading Housing First in the north-east, is planning to appoint some of the service users as peer support workers to provide role models for new people enrolling on the scheme.Cyrenians chief executive officer Mike Burns said: “These figures represent a signicant early success for Housing First.“Many of the people who are benefiting are people who have repeatedly identied themselves as homeless and who have cyclical needs.“Providing them with support through the project has helped free up resources for other people.“We are extremely pleased with the progress that has been made thanks to the partnership working between Cyrenians, Aberdeen Foyer, Turning Point Scotland and Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire councils.”One service user said: “I’ve been homeless about five times since I was .“I’d always just end up slipping back into addiction and intravenous use of heroin, taking fake Valium and stuff like that.“It was when Housing First Scotland got involved that I got this tenancy.“It is a brand new start for me.”The Scottish Government created a £. million pot to fund Housing First in October .Some of the cash came from funds raised by more than , people who slept out in Duthie Park one night in December  – an event organised by Social Bite, which also arranged sleep-out events in other parts of the country.Housing First will run until March  and is hoping to provide homes to at least  people by March .

story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered into a Galashiels man who admitted a total of three offences at Selkirk Sherf Court.Twenty year old Louis Heatlie pleaded guilty to assaulting a male to his injury in Gala Park on October  by repeatedly punching him to the head and body.He also admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner near his Glendinning Terrace home on November  by damaging a car windscreen with a pumpkin, adopting an aggressive attitude towards two named people and kicking a number of bins and a vehicle, as well as spitting on a police officer.Sherf Kevin Duffy said that in view of the nature of the offences he would be calling for a Criminal Justice Social Work Report and a Restriction of Liberty Order assessment.

title: good-behaviour-order-21-year-old-following-bust-up
story: A PEEBLES man who was involved in a bust-up with the mother of his young child has been ordered to be of good behaviour for the next four months at Selkirk Sherf Court.Twenty one year old Brandon Bisset pleaded guilty to shouting and swearing and struggling with his partner at a house in Dalatho Crescent, Peebles, on the morning of Tuesday, November .Alan Wickham, prosecuting, said a verbal altercation took place while they were out for a walk when the woman said she planned to go for a night out over the festive period.A struggle took place when they got back to the house with Bisset taking a young child from the womans arms.Defence lawyer Colin Severin said his client now lived with his parents and the relationship was over.He added that Bisset had regretted his actions and the fact the matter had ended up in court.

title: galashiels-girlguides-celebrates-100th-birthday
story: GALASHIELS will be celebrating a very important milestone this year as the st Galashiels Girlguiding unit turns .Members of the Guides, Rangers, Brownies and Rainbows will have the chance to celebrate this momentous birthday with events throughout the year, including a fun day in March and an afternoon tea for adult members or those who have volunteered with the group.Irene Sandie from Galashiels Girlguiding told us: "Wersquore hoping that all of the events wersquore having and other activities that we would like to be part of over the year might encourage new adult volunteers to get involved in Girlguiding. Wersquod really like to be able to offer more girls in our area the chance of enjoying Girlguiding and to do this we need more volunteers."Girlguiding has provided young girls and women opportunities to volunteer in their community, learn new skills, visit local and international sites and make new friends.Irene added: "Girlguiding has changed a lot over the last century and more but still adheres to the same aims and ambitions as those of our founding members."We offer a safe, welcoming girl-only space for all girls and young women to try new things, help other people and discover their passions and talent, all while having fun with a group of ready-made friends!"Were dedicated to girls leading the way - they choose activities, challenges and events that inspire them, and our volunteers support them to make it happen. Were always updating and adapting our activities so that theyrsquore relevant to girls today."Through fun, friendship, challenge and adventure we empower girls to find their voice, inspiring them to discover the best in themselves and to make a positive dference in their community."And to mark the occasion, unit leaders are putting together a centenary display to show how Girlguiding has changed in  years.To do this they are asking for any former members or volunteers to send in their pictures of past Guiding activities.Also,you have been involved as an adult volunteer with Galashiels Girlguiding at any time in the last  years, leaders want to hear from you too.To send any old Girlguiding photos, email galashielsdistrict@gmail or get in touch by phone at  .Former volunteers should send your name, unit, date of involvement and contact details to the same address.For more information on Girlguiding, visit https:www.girlguidingscotland.org.uk

title: glazing-firm-four-customers-collect-winnings
story: A BORDERS glazing firm is making sure a few of their customers are in the money.Everyone who completes a customer feedback questionnaire following work by Mitchell Glass is entered into a UK-wide prize draw.And every month one lucky winner collects pound.The cash-prize bonanza came about after the -year-old company joined Conservatory Outlet in A spokeswoman for Mitchell Glass told us: "Conservatory Outlet is an established UK wide network of home improvement companies, specialising in the installation of superior quality double glazing windows, replacement doors, conservatories and bespoke orangeries."Conservatory Outlet provides all its dealers with the most revolutionary and sought after home improvement products currently available."Not only benefitting from a superb home improvement, but when a customer of Mitchell Glass completes a customer feedback questionnaire, they are automatically entered into a prize draw run by Conservatory Outlet every month for a year and stand a chance of winning pound."The latest winner of the pound draw is Mrs Whoriskey from Duns who visited the showroom in Galashiels last week to claim her cheque.In her feedback review, Mrs Whoriskey stated: "Service from start to finish was excellent.
